subject: RE: [junit] Integrating JUNIT with Visual Age
msgSnippet: Background 1.The VAJ that Iam using is the freeware. Does this matter? 2.I have been using JUNIT successfully, it would be really nice not to have to debug
messageBody:
Background
1.The VAJ that Iam using is the freeware. Does this matter?
2.I have been using JUNIT successfully, it would be really nice not to have to debug with print statements!
3.I'm totally new to VAJ

If this works I'll get a cut of the real thing.

I blew away the project and started from scratch.

Per step one. I started importing stuff. If I only imported the source I could view it. But after I imported junit.jar I wasn't.

Sorry but I don't understand step two

-----Original Message-----
From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
Sent: Tuesday, July 10, 2001 7:55 AM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] Integrating JUNIT with Visual Age



> Hi my name is John
>
> I could use a couple of tips for integrating Junit into
> Visual Age for java
>
> I followed the steps outlined in the website.
>
> Created a new project for one of my working tests
>
> Put it in the project path for junit.textui.TestRunner
>
> But when I run the test it fails telling me "Could not
> invoke the suite() method"
>
> It can not find the static suite test method.

John... the way the documentation says to integrate JUnit is a little
clunky, although it follows the IBM standard. The easiest way I have found
to integrate any tool is to follow these steps:

1. fully import the source/binaries
2. create the tool directory and the default.ini for your tool
3. import the Tools API into your workspace
4. place any resource files you need into the tool directory (i.e. the gifs
for the awtui or swingui)
5. include the project that has your tool in the workspace classpath
(actually, its associated 'project_resources' folder)
6. include the Tools API project in your workspace classpath
7. compute the classpath for the class that launches your tool

This allows you to not have to export class files to that tool directory
every time you make a change to the tool.

About not finding the suite() method... that is a different story. Some
things to look at:
1. is your suite method public?
2. does your suite method have no argument?
3. if #1 and #2 hold true, get the source into VAJ and include a
printStackTrace() in the catch block that prints out "Could not invoke the
suite() method" and see what's going on.

> Another problem I am having is that in spite of the fact
> that I imported the source jar, when I double click
> on a class VA tells me that it has been imported from a
> class file. Also as a result I can not single step through
> the code.

This is boggling. Is it possible that you had a previous version of JUnit
in the workspace that was class files? This can cause a collision in VAJ,
even though it isn't supposed to. Are you sure you chose src.jar to import
from? If these things are not the case, then I would blow away the project
(purge the packages from the RepositoryExplorer) and try again.

-Jason
